content.raw:
I’ve made the above changes, and am merging. 

I’ll file a separate issue that there isn’t a docstring listing the various supported options. Many devices don’t have docstrings, but since this one doesn’t have separate args and kwargs for its options \(they all live in the \`camera\_attributes\` dict\), it’s even more undocumented than them.

Thanks Paco, and to all contributors and testers.
content.html:
I’ve made the above changes, and am merging.

I’ll file a separate issue that there isn’t a docstring listing the various supported options. Many devices don’t have docstrings, but since this one doesn’t have separate args and kwargs for its options (they all live in the `camera_attributes` dict), it’s even more undocumented than them.

Thanks Paco, and to all contributors and testers.

content.raw:
Sweeeeet.

* You can delete the `AndorSolis/runviewer_parsers.py` file - if there is no runviewer parser then you don’t need to define one.
* You can delete the contents of `__init__.py`. This is where you would do version checks, but you don’t have any particular verison requirements, so you can just leave `__init__.py` blank, with no copyright header either.

Copyright headers should say “Monash University and contributors”. Apologies for misleading copyright headers elsewhere. The situation is that Monash has copyright over the labscript suite as it was in 2013, and contributors since then retain copyright over anything they contribute \(and some people automatically assign copyright to their employer by virtue of their employment contract, others don’t\).
content.html:
Sweeeeet.

  • You can delete the AndorSolis/runviewer_parsers.py file - if there is no runviewer parser then you don’t need to define one.
  • You can delete the contents of __init__.py. This is where you would do version checks, but you don’t have any particular verison requirements, so you can just leave __init__.py blank, with no copyright header either.

Copyright headers should say “Monash University and contributors”. Apologies for misleading copyright headers elsewhere. The situation is that Monash has copyright over the labscript suite as it was in 2013, and contributors since then retain copyright over anything they contribute (and some people automatically assign copyright to their employer by virtue of their employment contract, others don’t).

content.raw:
Thanks for the feedback Russ! 

I just pushed the latest commits that try to incorporate the suggestions from your comments as well as some of the latest modifications coming from the lab \(where the iXon 888 is being extensively used both in kinetics and fast kinetics modes\).  However, notice that while some of these changes were brewed directly in the lab, the merged code remains untested as it stands. 

I will try to test it in the lab as soon as I can, but feel free to review the changes and please let me know if you have any comments. :grin:
content.html:
Thanks for the feedback Russ!

I just pushed the latest commits that try to incorporate the suggestions from your comments as well as some of the latest modifications coming from the lab (where the iXon 888 is being extensively used both in kinetics and fast kinetics modes). However, notice that while some of these changes were brewed directly in the lab, the merged code remains untested as it stands.

I will try to test it in the lab as soon as I can, but feel free to review the changes and please let me know if you have any comments.

content.raw:
Nice subclass! I tested this on an iXon 888 Ultra over USB3, and noticed the following:

* `self.number_of_preamp_gains` is overestimated by 1. For the camera I tested, `GetNumberPreAmpGains()` returned 3, but calling `GetPreAmpGain(2)` returned code 20066 \(`DRV_P1INVALID`\). Weird given you tested with the same model.
* `check_output` is not fit for use in `GetTemperature` and `GetTemperatureF` as it raises an `AndorException` for non-null return codes that represent a valid status.
* The commented-out example code in `__main__` of andor\_utils.py is super useful for debugging outside of BLACS/labscript, but contains deprecated functions like `snap` and `grab_acquisition`. Can you update it to reflect the current functions?
* The `enable_cooldown` function in andor\_utils.py:

    * assumes water cooling is present and turns fans off \(make this optional\)
    * isn’t used anywhere in blacs\_workers.py. Why? \(Presumably you control the cooling using another tool like SOLIS?\)
    * should print temperature and status while temperature is stabilising.
    * has erroneous bounds checking for the set point. See suggestion in code comment.
    
* andor\_solis.py only looks for the DLL in a SOLIS directory. Fallback to looking in the SDK directory.

‌
content.html:
Nice subclass! I tested this on an iXon 888 Ultra over USB3, and noticed the following:

  • self.number_of_preamp_gains is overestimated by 1. For the camera I tested, GetNumberPreAmpGains() returned 3, but calling GetPreAmpGain(2) returned code 20066 (DRV_P1INVALID). Weird given you tested with the same model.
  • check_output is not fit for use in GetTemperature and GetTemperatureF as it raises an AndorException for non-null return codes that represent a valid status.
  • The commented-out example code in __main__ of andor_utils.py is super useful for debugging outside of BLACS/labscript, but contains deprecated functions like snap and grab_acquisition. Can you update it to reflect the current functions?

  • The enable_cooldown function in andor_utils.py:

    • assumes water cooling is present and turns fans off (make this optional)
    • isn’t used anywhere in blacs_workers.py. Why? (Presumably you control the cooling using another tool like SOLIS?)
    • should print temperature and status while temperature is stabilising.
    • has erroneous bounds checking for the set point. See suggestion in code comment.

  • andor_solis.py only looks for the DLL in a SOLIS directory. Fallback to looking in the SDK directory.

‌

content.raw:
Update the commented example code in `__main__` to reflect current usage, e.g. `snap` no longer exists.

First test might read:

```
cam = AndorCam()
cam.enable_cooldown(10)
cam.setup_acquisition(added_attributes={'exposure_time':25*ms,})
cam.acquire()
images = cam.download_acquisition()
print(f'Exposure time was {cam.exposure_time}')
```

This code is super useful for debugging outside of BLACS/labscript.
content.html:
Update the commented example code in __main__ to reflect current usage, e.g. snap no longer exists.

First test might read:

cam = AndorCam()
cam.enable_cooldown(10)
cam.setup_acquisition(added_attributes={'exposure_time':25*ms,})
cam.acquire()
images = cam.download_acquisition()
print(f'Exposure time was {cam.exposure_time}')

This code is super useful for debugging outside of BLACS/labscript.

content.raw:
Append print statement:

`print(f"Temperature not reached: T = {self.temperature}")`
Make the fan mode a keyword argument, i.e. don’t assume water cooling.
content.html: Make the fan mode a keyword argument, i.e. don’t assume water cooling.

content.raw:
This bounds checking is incorrect and should read:

`if temperature_setpoint < self.temperature_range[0] or temperature_setpoint > self.temperature_range[1])`
content.html:
This bounds checking is incorrect and should read:

if temperature_setpoint < self.temperature_range[0] or temperature_setpoint > self.temperature_range[1])

content.raw: As implemented, `check_status` is not fit for use here \(or below in `GetTemperatureF`\) as it raises `AndorException` for what is a valid non-null result here, i.e. these functions don’t actually return the `(temperature, status)` tuple because this call always raises an `AndorException`.
content.html: As implemented, check_status is not fit for use here (or below in GetTemperatureF) as it raises AndorException for what is a valid non-null result here, i.e. these functions don’t actually return the (temperature, status) tuple because this call always raises an AndorException.

content.raw: Add a fallback to `C:\Program Files\Andor SDK` for users that have only the SDK installed.
content.html: Add a fallback to C:\Program Files\Andor SDK for users that have only the SDK installed.
